inlineContent.text: contains information about an image’s pixel data,
its color space, bits per sample, width and height, and the
rowstride (the number of bytes between the start of one row
and the start of the next).
The most basic way to create a pixbuf is to wrap an existing pixel
buffer with a [class
] instance. You can use the
GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new_from_data``] function to do this.
Every time you create a new
instance for some data, you
will need to specify the destroy notification function that will be
called when the data buffer needs to be freed; this will happen when
a
is finalized by the reference counting functions. If
you have a chunk of static data compiled into your application, you
can pass in
as the destroy notification function so that the
data will not be freed.
The [
GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new

inlineContent.code: ] constructor function can be used as a convenience to create a pixbuf with an empty buffer; this is equivalent to allocating a data buffer using

inlineContent.text: malloc()
gdk_pixbuf_new_from_data()
gdk_pixbuf_new()``
function will compute an optimal rowstride so that rendering can be
performed with an efficient algorithm.
As a special case, you can use the [
GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new_from_xpm_data``]
function to create a pixbuf from inline XPM image data.
You can also copy an existing pixbuf with the [method
function. This is not the same as just acquiring a reference to
the old pixbuf instance: the copy function will actually duplicate
the pixel data in memory and create a new [class
] instance
for it.
structures are reference counted. This means that an
application can share a single pixbuf among many parts of the
code. When a piece of the program needs to use a pixbuf, it should
acquire a reference to it by calling
; when it no
longer needs the pixbuf, it should release the reference it acquired
by calling
. The resources associated with a
will be freed when its reference count drops to zero.
Newly-created
instances start with a reference count
of one.
Image data in a pixbuf is stored in memory in an uncompressed,
packed format. Rows in the image are stored top to bottom, and
in each row pixels are stored from left to right.
There may be padding at the end of a row.
The “rowstride” value of a pixbuf, as returned by [
GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.get_rowstride``],
indicates the number of bytes between rows.
NOTE
: If you are copying raw pixbuf data with
note that the
last row in the pixbuf may not be as wide as the full rowstride, but rather
just as wide as the pixel data needs to be; that is: it is unsafe to do
to copy a whole pixbuf. Use
[method
] instead, or compute the width in bytes of the
last row as:
The same rule applies when iterating over each row of a
pixels
array.
The following code illustrates a simple
function for RGB pixbufs with 8 bits per channel with an alpha
channel.

code: // Ensure that the pixbuf is valid
// Ensure that the coordinates are in a valid range
// The pixel buffer in the GdkPixbuf instance
// The pixel we wish to modify
guchar *p = pixels + y * rowstride + x * n_channels;

inlineContent.text: The
class provides a simple mechanism for loading
an image from a file in synchronous and asynchronous fashion.
For GUI applications, it is recommended to use the asynchronous
stream API to avoid blocking the control flow of the application.
Additionally,
provides the [class``PixbufLoader```]
API for progressive image loading.
The
class provides methods for saving image data in
a number of file formats. The formatted data can be written to a
file or to a memory buffer.
can also call a user-defined
callback on the data, which allows to e.g. write the image
to a socket or store it in a database.
The
type acts as a lightweight Swift reference to an underlying
instance.
It exposes methods that can operate on this data type through
conformance.
Use
only as an
reference to an existing
instance.
Use
(instead of
) if you want to use Automatic Reference Counting for memory management of the underlying
instance.
